title: What is HEIC Format? Everything You Need to Know
excerpt: Learn about HEIC format, why Apple uses it, and how it compares to traditional image formats like JPEG and PNG.

content.text: HEIC (High Efficiency Image Container) is a modern image format developed by the Moving Picture Experts Group (MPEG). Since iOS 11, Apple has used HEIC as the default format for photos taken on iPhones and iPads.
Why HEIC is Better Than JPEG

HEIC offers several advantages over traditional JPEG format. The most significant benefit is file size - HEIC files are typically 40-50% smaller than equivalent JPEG files while maintaining the same image quality. This means you can store twice as many photos on your device without sacrificing quality.
Key Features of HEIC

items: Can store multiple images in one file
Smaller file sizes save storage space

content.text: The Compatibility Challenge

While HEIC is technically superior, it's not universally supported. Many older devices, Windows computers (before Windows 10), and web browsers can't open HEIC files natively. This is why converting HEIC to more compatible formats like JPEG or PNG is often necessary.
If you need to share photos with friends, upload to websites, or use older software, converting to JPEG or PNG ensures compatibility across all platforms.

title: HEIC vs JPG: Which Format Should You Use?
excerpt: Detailed comparison between HEIC and JPG formats to help you choose the right format for your needs.

content.text: Both HEIC and JPG are popular image formats, but they serve different purposes. Understanding the differences can help you choose the right format for your needs.
File Size Comparison

HEIC files are significantly smaller than JPG files. On average, a HEIC file is 40-50% smaller than an equivalent quality JPG file. This means if a JPG file is 3MB, the same image in HEIC format would be approximately 1.5-1.8MB.
Image Quality

Despite smaller file sizes, HEIC maintains equal or better image quality compared to JPG. HEIC supports 16-bit color depth while JPG is limited to 8-bit, resulting in more accurate colors and smoother gradients in HEIC images.
Compatibility

When to Use HEIC

items: Storing photos on your iPhone or iPad
Sharing photos with other Apple device users

content.text: When to Use JPG

items: Sharing photos online or via email
Uploading to websites or social media
Working with older devices or software

content.text: The Bottom Line

HEIC is technically superior with better compression and quality, but JPG remains the practical choice for sharing and compatibility. Many users find it best to keep photos in HEIC on their devices and convert to JPG when sharing.
